page.lettertext:
fol.183r
Belgia
15
91
23
July To my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: July.
May it please yo
r
good L. to be advertised, that as
I was willed by my
LL. of
e Councel
. I acquainted
Count
Maurice
w
th
her
Ma
t
request, for some assistance of ships
to be p
nt
ly employed against
e Indies fleet, But as I
signified to my LL. in
e answere, w
ch
I sent
e 13 of
this moneth, the Count
authority would not stretch to
e
setting forth of anye shippes, it was a matt
r
of great
expens, & required
e resolution of
e g
na
l states
in
t
behalf,
who then resided at
e
Hage.
Albeit I had
no charge to sollicit
e states in
t
behalf, & Count
Maurice his answer had put mee clean out of hope
of speeding in my motion, yet becaus I
ceaved
t
nothing could be don, but by meanes of
e states,
I addressed forth w
th
a letter unto them, requesting both
e
Count &
e
Councel of state
to doo
e like. Howbeyt
before o
r
letters came unto them, the whole assembly of
e states were coming to
is towne. wherby
e letters were
undelivered, But I dealt w
th
them heer assoone as
they came, omitting nothing
t
I thought might drawe
them forward to do somewhat, Theyr answere unto
mee was
e same in effect, as I receaved of Co. Maurice.
That they had no shippes of that burden that was
posed,
That
e shortnes of time would
mit th
e
to do nothing
That w
th
out
e pritivy & warrant of
e Provinces w
ch
could not be
cured und
r
4 or 5 weekes, they could
take no resolution. That they douted th
r
in the
rest
incli-
nation of
e Provinces, by reason of this warre that is
so burdensome unto th
e
, as they are ev
r
y daye forced to
extraordinary charges, having gathered this yeare verye
great contributions, aswell for
e augmenta
o
n of their
forces, as for the
e assistance of
France
w
th
mony & oth
r
wise
This was it in substance w
ch
they signified unto mee
wh
r
in they were so setled, as no reply would p
r
vaile,
w
ch
I humbly beseech yo
u
, occasyon requiring, to report
unto the LL. They have now made an end of theyr
long consultation about
e course of theyr traffique
aswell w
th
e ennemy elswhere as in
Spaine.
I have
not seen yt as yet, nor it is not yet freely set downe
fol.183v
Belgia: 1591: July.
in writing: but they are still buisied about yt, & when it
is finished they will exhibit it unto mee. Heer is nothing
yet resolved, about
e next employm
t
of o
r
forces, w
ch
will depend altogeth
r
upon
e ennemyes cowrses, of w
ch
nothing more is knowen then I signified in my last, of
his encamping by
Nieumegen.
The brute doth yet
continew of his going for France, w
ch
is hardly
beleeved of many men heer: for that then it is thought
hee should loose undoutedly both
Nieumegen,
&
Bosleducke
& leave many oth
r
places for a pray to o
r
armye, w
ch
mighte happely occasyon a g
na
l revolt. There is a
speech at this p
nt
that
Verdugo
shal returne toward
Groningen,
w
th
his former forces, & a furder renforcem
t
.
The mutins of
Diest
&
Herentals,
do
sist in theyr
mutiny, as wee are advertised. Such among them as
have made incursyons into
Liege,
& spoyled
e Countrey
upon
e entercession of
e cleargy of
Liege
, are
excommunicate by
e
Pope.
Wh
r
uppon
e mutins, besydes
that pay w
ch
they have heth
r
too demanded, require to bee
absolved of
e forsayd excomunication, w
ch
they refuse
to receave, & p
r
cisely stand upon it, unles yt bee
confirmed by
e Popes owne hand. Upon a g
na
l revewe
that is made of this campe, as it lyeth now by
Arnham
, they are found to be 7200 footmen,
from
& 1600 horse, no absent
, nor sick, nor hurt
sons
accounted. There is also expected an augmentation
of theyr footmen, from divers of theyr garrisons,
knowing
no oth
r
matt
r
worthy
e advertisement I take my &c.
Fr
o
Arnham. July 23 1591.
